titleStmt.title: H. His deuises, for his owne exercise, and his friends pleasure
titleStmt.author: Howell, Thomas, fl. 1568-1581.

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A03755 of text S113292 in the English Short Title Catalog (STC 13875). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 170 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 52 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Evanston,IL, Notre Dame, IN, St. Louis, MO

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal . The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: H. His deuises, for his owne exercise, and his friends pleasure
titleStmt.author: Howell, Thomas, fl. 1568-1581.

publicationStmt.publisher: In Fleetestreate, beneath the conduite, at the signe of the Saint Iohn Euangelist, by [W. How? for] H. Iackson,

notesStmt.note: Running title reads: Delightfull discourses to sundry purposes.
First leaf blank; last leaf, M6, missigned M4.
Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.
